А
September 1933.
Dear tattles,
We are now flying from Foochow to Shanghai on the
last leg of our survey flight to the Phillipines - and will soon
complete trip covering 4,400 miles altogether. We have had
some interesting experiences, but really and literally "nothing
to write home about so this letter will just sort of ramble
along.
The most interesting part of the trip was the one
to Zamboanga from Manila.
A year ago, there was an American over here,
named Brophy, who started out from Macao near Hongkong, to
fly to Manila.
He was
inexperienced, had a defective com-
pass and couldn't have made the trip with the amount of gas
that he carried.
The sad, or at least one sad part of the
story was that he took a dog with him. Well anyway, nothing
was ever heard of Brophy, and the general public uninformed
on the facts regarded the flight as extremely hazardous. As
a result in Manila, we were given a lot of credit for being
brave, or criticism for being fool-hardy - neither of which
was deserved.
The flight from Hongkong to the Island of Iuzon
is only a little over 500 miles and with a compass anywhere
near right it would be hard to miss Luzon and the Phillipine
Islands.
The weather reports for that section of the
world are probably the most reliable and dependable available
anywhere.
During the last sixty years, the French at
Shanghai, and the Spanish at Manila, Jesuit Fathers have
G. 32. 1000 18-8•33 M. P. C.

herd.
( 2 )
ridden hard on typhoons until there is little danger that
one will catch shiyping unawares especially now with radios.
Out in the China Sea where typhoons occur as frequently as
six times per month during the season - July, August, Sep-
tember, they pay a lot of attention to weather in general
and Father Selga of Manila in particular.
The typhoons,
almost all are born in the area betwen Guam and the Philip-
pines - at first the center of the typhoons moors at a
speed of 7 to 10 miles per hour, while the velocities arouna
the center may reach 100 miles, later the center moves fas-
ter, but seldom over 20 miles yer hour in the China Sea.
The typhoons move from their starting place toward the
West, usually passing along the Northern end of Iuzon (rarely
getting as far South as Manila) toward the Southern coast
of China. They near the coast, generally moving along the
China coast over Korea, Japan and the North Pacific. Before
we left Honghong for Manila, we knew what the weather was
all the way through, and the same thing coming back - and
the reports were perfect. We had a tug standing by at
Hongkong in case of trouble, and we were in touch by radio
sheps
with things on and near our course the entire way. On
each crossing the ocean was quiet, and we could have landed
safely anytime. So all the heroics or rashness was equally
unwarranted. At any rate the people in Manila were certain-
ly grand to us - high officials dropped whatever they were
doing and gave us all sort of statistics which it would
have taken weeks to get any other way. The business commu-
nity of Manila were just as anxious to co-operate - also
G. 32. 1000 18-8-33 M. P. C.

( 3 )
the Navy and wireless people etc. and probably the best of
all the hely and assistance was from the Dollar Company
which will of course feel the competition of air trans-
port.
Hohn and Marjory Holliday were very helpful and
thoughtful. They gave a party for us, and had Governor
Gent Murphy, so that we met him under favourable circum-
stances, and were well sponsored right from the kick-off.
John is highly regarded by everyone in the Philippines
and could have had an appointment as one of the Judges
of the Supreme Court of the Islands but"he did not chose
to run".
We left Manila Bay Sunday morning just as the sun
was rising. A low ground haze-or fog covered all the
valleys - through this shroudlike formation, the mountains
stuck up into a bright, almost cloudless sky. We flew
up to Linguan Bay where for safety sake, we refuelad so
we had 9 hours
gas supply for a flight of only about 5
hours.
Leaving Luzon, we flew a course which we hoped
we would take us over the Pratas Island, but again we missed
that Island.
The triy across was uneventful. Except for
a few local showers, the weather was perfect and while we
missed Pratas Island, we managed to hit Hongkong"right on
the nose".
We landed there a little after 1 p.m. and
had lunch at the Hotel, and then Mr. Scott, Managing Direc-
tor of Far Eastern Aviation showed us around Hongkong. We
G. 32. 1000 | 3.8.33 M.?.C

( 4 )
crossed from the leased territory of Kowloon on one of the huge
ferries which plies back and forth. Arriving at Hongkong, we
motored up to Mr. Scott's home, which is about 1000 ft above
the Harbour.
He has a beautiful house and garden, with a
view of the Harbour which is hard to beat. We then drove
around the Island to Repulse Bay and had a swim.
The bay is
unusually beautiful with a perfect sand beach.
After the swim,
Mr. Scott drove us up the Peak.
Peak Hotel is on the highest
point of the Island.
When Father and Mother visited Hongkong,
the only means of reaching the Peak was by a tram-car, but now
there is a good automobile road from the Ferry up.
The best
way to describe Hongkong is to say it very much resembles the
view you would get from Dome Island of Buck Mountain --- if you
can imagine Buck Mountain almost entirely covered with attractive
homes connected by a good motor high-way, with the Peak Hotel
on top.
The altitude and grades are about the same as Buck
Mountain.
The view from Kowloon is equivalent to that faem
Buck Mountain
How Dome Island.
It is the most amazing and
beatiful sight I have ever seen.
There is nothing real about
it at all. The lights come on close together against the
black back-ground of the mountains, and the whole setting looks
most unreal.
We returned to the Hotel and left the following
morning at day-break, flying along the coast to Foochow.. The
most interesting thing to observe along the. Chinese coast is
the clever traps which are built to catch the poor fish. Every
conceivable method is employed, but the most common is a

( 5 )
fence-like net, shaped like a "vit with the wide ends bound to-
wards the land, and at the small end of the "y" is a trap made
like one of our minow buckets. The whole arrangement so laid
out is to trap any fish which comes near shore when the tide
is in, and takes his time about leaving when the tide goes out.
You see miles and miles of these traps, sometimes 3 to 4 deep.
and as the tide goes out the men are working at the small end
of the "y" letting the fishes into baskets or where the opera-
tion is condueted in a larger scale into waggons drawn by
Water buffaloes.
As we approached Foochow, our radio operator
started
"talking" to the operator on the President Hoover, and
we received a request from the Captain of the Hoover to pay
him a call at sea. We then changed our course slightly and
about 20 miles out sea, we sighted the Hoover on its way from
Shanghai to Hongkong and Manila. We flew very low over the
ship and threw some Sunday Manila newspapers (this was about
10 o'clock Monday morning) on board. We rolled the papers ur
tight and bound them with wire, and a little later as we cir-
oled the ship, the Hoover's operator sent greetings from the
Captain thanking us for the call and stated that he would frame
one of the papers. We in return sent message thanking him
for his salute which we saw, but did not hear " 3 puffs of steam
from the whistle". Leaving the Hoover we went on to Foochow.
You may remember some reports about the American Consul at
Foochow asking for an American battleship to be sent there on
account of communistic raids. We got there while the situa-
tion was at its worst. The Communists who are really or-
ganized bandits, were operating approximately 100 miles North
0. 32. 1000 18•855 Mr.

( 6 )
West of Foochow.
Their practice is to surround a city, plunder,
loot and rob everyone and everything within the city and then
set fire to the place, so that wherever they go they leave be-
hind a bankrupt and really ruined community.
This particular
coup seems to be well lead and had been so successful, it
appeared certain that they would close in on Foochow and on
account of that, the port was given protection by battleships.
The Consul at Foochow is a good friend of ours, and we spent
a good interesting half an hour talking about the situation,
while the plane was being refueled. We then took off for
Shanghai and arrived here about 4 p.m., to hear all about a
typhoon which had caused lots of damage the day before. So
far as we know, our flight was the first one ever made from
Manila to Shanghai.

until now Sept. 30h. The gues
